Beamswords and Bazookas is a tabletop role-playing game about mech pilots at the brink of World War III. Players will create a character and guide this character through harrowing adventures. When these characters attempt to do something dangerous, players will roll dice to see if they are successful or not. One player, referred to as the gamemaster, will narrate the situation, play as the opposition, and guide the pace of the game. Together, all the players will create a story and play through it in real time. Winning is nice, but the goal of this game is to experience a compelling adventure that’s created collectively with your friends.

Much of the action in Beamswords and Bazookas takes place in the imagination of the players. Each person should strive to describe their character’s actions as clearly and vibrantly as possible to ensure that everyone shares the same vision. Many mech battles will use miniatures, maps, and rulers to reflect tactical fights. But, even in these encounters, painting the scene through vivid narration will enhance everyone’s experience.

If some of these basic role playing game concepts sound a bit foreign to you, there is no better resource for learning how to play a tabletop RPG than seeing one in action. Your local game store likely has regular game nights that would welcome new players. And, there are many “live play” podcasts and video series available on the internet which contain hours of example play. Both are great resources if you’ve never played a game like this before.

If you’re ready to start creating a character and building your mech, you can find the steps for doing so on page 10. But, understanding the rules and reviewing the character options available beforehand might help your decision making during character creation. You can see the Basic Rules section on page 14 and the Actions section on page 28 for an explanation of the general gameplay mechanics. And, the Attributes section on page 35, the Mech Weapons section on page 40, and the Traits section on page 46 will cover many of the options available when determining your character’s strengths, weaknesses, and abilities. Also, you can find character sheets and other resources for play at www.sweaterpunkstudios.com.

This book refers to different sizes of dice with specific abbreviations. A six-sided die is referred to as a D6. An eight-sided die is referred to as a D8. A ten-sided die is referred to as a D10. And, a twelve-sided die is referred to as a D12. You will need dice of these sizes in order to play.

What is a mech? A mech is a large robotic vehicle that is piloted by a person who rides inside it. They are often humanoid in shape and heavily armed. While they can come in many sizes, this game assumes they are 2-3 stories tall. Beamswords and Bazookas is about the pilots who are brave enough to steer these warmachines into battle.

Many Traits and Mech Weapons have names which define their fictional representation. But, you are encouraged to re-imagine any character options as you see fit. For example, the Mech Trait “Aerofoils” is meant to represent your mech having mechanical wings. However, if you’d like to envision this as a giant rocket on your mech’s back instead, feel free! As long as it doesn’t effect the game mechanics, you can adjust the flavor of character options to suit your needs.
C H A R A C T E R
C R E A T I O N

Assign a D6, a D8, a D10, and a D12 to your four different Character Attributes. Then do the same for your Mech Attributes and your Skill Attributes. For more information, see the Attributes section starting on page 35.

Choose 1 Character Trait, 1 Mech Trait, and 1 Skill Trait. Then choose 3 Bonus Traits of any kind. You will have 6 Traits in total. Note that some Traits have requirements which must be met in order to select them. For more information, see the Traits section starting on page 46.

You may choose Mech Weapons that you can equip to 2 Hard-points. Each Mech Weapon occupies 1 Hardpoint unless noted otherwise. The total Weight of your Mech Weapons and Mech Traits cannot exceed your Load Rating. For more information, see the Mech Weapons section starting on page 40.

Your character is more than just the operator of a giant war machine. Choose a Character Name, a Mech Callsign, a Virtue, and a Vice that represent who they are as a person. Your character will need to deal with the Stress that conflict creates by engaging in their Virtue and/or their Vice between Encounters. Choose a Virtue and a Vice that deepens your character’s motivations and inspires the personal moments you want to explore. For example Virtue and Vice options and to learn more about Stress, see pages 21-22.
You start with 1 Mech Armor which can be expended to avoid Damage once per Encounter. Determine additional Derived Ratings as follows:

Load Rating determines how much Weight you can carry and is derived from your Drive Attribute. It is equal to the highest value of your Drive Die. A D6 Drive Die equals 6 Load Rating, A D8 Drive Die equals 8 Load Rating, A D10 Drive Die equals 10 Load Rating. And a D12 Drive Die equals 12 Load Rating.

Energy Rating determines how much Energy you start with at the beginning of each Encounter and is derived from your Systems Attribute. It is equal to the highest value of your Systems Die. A D6 Systems Die equals 6 Energy Rating. A D8 Systems Die equals 8 Energy Rating. A D10 Systems Die equals 10 Energy Rating. And a D12 Systems Die equals 12 Energy Rating.

Stress Limit represents how much emotional turmoil your character can withstand and is derived from your Wits Attribute. It is equal to the highest value of your Wits Die plus 4. A D6 Wits Die equals a 10 Stress Limit. A D8 Wits Die equals a 12 Stress Limit. A D10 Wits Die equals a 14 Stress Limit. And, a D12 Wits Die equals a 16 Stress Limit.
Carried Weight is the total Weight of all Mech Weapons and Mech Traits. It cannot exceed your Load Rating.

Move Rating represents how far your mech can travel when you take a Move Action. Each mech starts with a base Move Rating of 4. But, your Move Rating is affected by both your mech’s Load Rating and your Carried Weight. Subtract your Carried Weight from your Load Rating and divide the difference by 2, rounding down. Add this value to your starting Move Rating of 4 to get your final Move Rating.

In other words, you gain +1 Move Rating for every 2 full points of Load Rating you aren’t currently using. If you have a Load Rating of 8 and a Carried Weight of 6, then you’ll gain +1 Move Rating and have a total Move Rating of 5.

When your character attempts an action that is risky or difficult, you will need to roll dice in order to determine whether or not they succeed. If you roll a 5 or higher, then they are successful. Successfully rolling a 5 is referred to as a Hit. And, if you do not roll at least a 5, then you do not get a Hit and the attempted action fails.

The dice you roll to determine success or failure are based on your character’s Attributes. You will generally roll a combination of two Attribute Dice which are chosen based on the situation and the attempted action. For example, if your character is piloting their mech and attempting to shoot an enemy with their equipped Machine Gun, then you will roll their Precision Die and their Arsenal Die. If either of the dice rolled results in at least a 5, then you score a Hit and the attempt is successful. Dice are not added together. Each individual die result is checked to determine if a Hit was rolled. The Actions section on page 28 and the Attributes section on page 35 have detailed explanations of which Attributes are applicable in any given situation.

When you make a roll to determine success, you might receive more than one Hit. Each die you roll that is at least a 5 is a Hit. A die roll of 10 or more is two Hits. Many actions you take will have bonus effects when you roll Extra Hits, or any Hit you receive in excess of what is needed for a success.
A roll which results in a 2 and a 3 counts as 0 Hits
A roll which results in a 4 and a 6 counts as 1 Hit
A roll which results in a 7 and a 5 counts as 2 Hits
A roll which results in an 11 and a 1 counts as 2 Hits
A roll which results in a 10 and a 9 counts as 3 Hits

Especially challenging actions may require 2 or 3 Hits in order to succeed. In these situations, you do not have to score all of the Hits needed for success on a single roll. Hits scored on separate attempts all count toward the total number of Hits needed to succeed. However, you must score at least 1 Hit to avoid failure. If you make an attempt and score 0 Hits, then you have failed and may not make additional attempts to succeed. If you score at least 1 Hit, but do not get enough Hits to succeed, then the situation will become more difficult and a Complication will need to be dealt with before you can make another attempt.

For example, losing a pursuer who is chasing you might requires 3 Hits in order to succeed. In this scenario, you might be required to roll multiple times over the course of a high-speed chase. If you receive 1 Hit on the first attempt, you trigger a Complication. The Complication in this case is an enemy jumping on the hood of the vehicle and attempting to attack your character. Players must resolve this new situation before trying again to lose the pursuer. If you deal with the enemy on the hood and score 2 Hits on the next attempt to lose the pursuer, then you successfully escape. Even though you only rolled 2 Hits and losing the pursuer requires 3, the Hit from the first attempt counts towards the overall success of the action.

Sometimes a roll you make will be Contested. This means another character will be attempting to oppose your action. Your highest die roll will have to exceed the highest result of the opposing character’s roll in order to succeed. You can receive Extra Hits on a Contested roll if your result is 5 greater than the opposing roll or if multiple dice exceed the opposing character’s highest die result.

The actions of players and enemies are sequenced by handing out cards at the beginning of each Encounter. Remove all of the spades from a standard deck of playing cards and shuffle the spades together. Then, deal a card to each player and to each opposing force. Each character, or group of characters, then takes their Turn, proceeding from high card to low card. Once all Turns are taken, the spade cards are shuffled together and dealt out again for the next round. Adhering to initiative order is imperative during Mech Encounters as mech combat actions are highly structured and restricted. It is recommended to use initiative order for Character Encounters as well in order to ensure players receive equal attention and to establish the passage of time.
Each character takes actions on their Turn. The actions available to them differ depending on whether it is a Mech Encounter or a Character Encounter.

If it is a Mech Encounter, each character can take a Mech Action, a Pilot Action, and Move Action on their Turn. These actions can be taken in any order and the options available are described in detail in the Actions section on page 28. Here is a brief overview of each:
Mech Actions are the primary functions that mechs perform, including attacking with Mech Weapons.
Pilots Actions are extra actions that characters perform in order to gain an edge in combat.
Move Actions allow mechs to travel a distance equal to their Move Rating.

If it is a Character Encounter, each player can take a Skill  Action on their Turn and is assumed to be able to move a reasonable distance. See the Skill Actions section on page 32 for more information and a detailed list of available Skill Actions.

Whenever characters engage in a conflict or risky situation, it is called an Encounter. Encounters last until the situation is resolved or until characters actively remove themselves from the situation. When characters pilot their mechs and engage hostile enemies in a battle, this is considered a Mech Encounter. Mech Encounters should be played with miniatures so that distances can be accurately tracked. Move Ratings and Ranges are given as relative numbers for use on a 1-inch grid or when using a tape measure to check distances. But, other increments can be used if needed. All mechs are assumed to occupy 1 unit of measurement.

Character Encounters occur when characters find themselves engaged in a dangerous situation while they are not piloting their mechs. These Encounters will sometimes involve combat, but are just as likely to involve a car chase, a heated conversation, or an attempt to break into a high security facility. Therefore, Character Encounters are often easier to represent through the descriptions of the players in a theater-of-the-mind.
There are instances when a character might find themselves outside of their mech during a Mech Encounter. When this happens, make sure to follow these Scale Crossover Rules:
If a character would be represented outside of their mech on a Mech Encounter battlefield, they are considered to have a Move Rating of 4 and they can move through spaces occupied by a mech.
Ranged weapons carried by the character have a Range value equal to their maximum Soldier Die value, but cannot damage a mech unless the character has the Anti-Mech Weaponry Skill Trait.

Hitting a character who is not in a vehicle with a Mech Weapon is harder than hitting a large target and incurs Disadvantage. If a character would receive a Hit from a Mech Weapon while they are not piloting their mech, they are Dying.

When you are hit by an attack while piloting your mech, you must immediately roll to Defend. Roll your Toughness and Hull  Attribute Dice and compare your result to the attacker’s Weapon Rating. Unlike most other rolls, all dice rolled when you Defend with your mech are added together as one total sum. Resolve the attack as follows:
If your Defend roll meets or exceeds the attacker’s Damage Rating, then you successfully block the attack and it causes no Damage.
If your Defend roll does not meet your opponent’s Damage Rating, you are Rattled.

If your Defend roll is 5 fewer than your opponent’s Damage Rating, then you receive Damage in addition to being Rattled. For each additional increment of 5 below your opponent’s Damage Rating you roll, you will take an additional Damage.

If you are granted an Advantage on your Defend roll, you may add the Advantage die to the total sum rolled. If you have Disadvantages on your Defend roll, add together only your two lowest dice results.

Characters often become Rattled as a result of being attacked and are temporarily less effective while Rattled. If a Rattled character would become Rattled again, they instead take Damage or an Injury. You cannot benefit from Advantages when Rattled and you cannot make Opportunity Attacks. You can recover from being Rattled by taking a Recover Pilot Action, taking a Willpower Skill Action, or by Pushing. See the Actions section on page 28 and Pushing on page 22 for more info.

When you receive Damage, roll a D6 and suffer the corresponding result on the Damage Table below. If all 4 of your Mech’s Attribute Dice are Damaged (Results 1-4), the mech is no longer structurally sound and the pilot must immediately eject. If you would receive a result more than once, you may instead choose a different result. The one exception to this is the Direct Hit result.
You can no longer roll your Arsenal die.
You can no longer roll your Drive die and your Move Rating is halved, rounded down.
You can no longer roll your Hull die.
You can no longer roll your Systems die or regain Energy.
Your pilot suffers 1 Injury. If you receive this result twice in an Encounter, your pilot is Dying.
Choose one of the above results.

If a character attempts to harm another Character with a Skill Action in a Character Encounter, the target of the attack will Defend by rolling their Speed and Toughness Attribute Dice in response. Any Hits on this Defense roll will cancel out Hits on the attack roll. The first Hit a character takes will cause them to become Rattled. Once Rattled, each additional Hit will cause an Injury.

When you receive an Injury, roll a D6 and suffer an Injury corresponding to the Injury Table. If your character would receive an Injury to all 4 Attributes (Injuries 1-4), they are Dying. If you would receive a result more than once, you may choose a different Injury instead.
You can’t roll your Precision Die.
You can’t roll your Speed Die.
You can’t roll your Toughness Die.
You can’t roll your Wits Die.
You can’t roll any Skill Dice.
Choose one of the above results.

Your character receives 1 Stress whenever they are successfully attacked. This is true at both Mech Scale and Character Scale. They receive this Stress whether they are successful on their Defend roll or not. If your character accumulates Stress which exceeds their Stress Limit, roll a D6 and they suffer the corresponding result from the Psychosis Table.
You are frozen and can’t act.
You must attack each Turn. The targets of your attacks are chosen randomly.
You are Rattled and cannot recover from being Rattled this Encounter.
You eject from your mech and end up adjacent to it
Choose one of the above results.
In addition to Stress received from being attacked, you can choose to Push your character and receive 3 Stress in order to gain one of the following benefits.

You cannot Push if doing so would cause you to exceed your Stress Limit. You can Push multiple times per action to re-roll or avoid multiple Hits when Defending. The final consequences of a roll must be resolved and Stress must be received before another action and/or roll may be initiated.

Out of combat, your character can relieve all of their Stress by engaging in their Virtue or their Vice. It will be important for your character to seek out opportunities to relieve Stress or they will quickly become overwhelmed on the battlefield. You are encouraged to add story elements for your character which allow you to engage in your Virtue or your Vice narratively.
Example Virtues - Courage, Leadership, Loyalty, Humility, Generosity, Empathy, Idealism, Wisdom, Diplomacy, Patience
Example Vices - Laziness, Theft, Infidelity, Melancholy, Narcissism, Anger, Violence, Lying, Addiction, Rowdiness

Your character is Dying if they receive an Injury to each Character Attribute, if they are directly attacked by a Mech Weapon, or if they receive the Direct Hit Damage result twice in an Encounter. If your character is Dying, they will die permanently if not immediately stabilized by a successful Medicine Skill Action. Even if stabilized, a Dying character requires immediate hospitalization and time to recover.

Environmental factors, Traits, and different actions might make rolls harder or easier. These conditional modifiers are called Advantages and Disadvantages. If you have both an Advantage and a Disadvantage on the same action, they cancel each other out.

An Advantage adds a D6 Advantage Die to your roll. If you would have multiple Advantages, you may increase the size of this Advantage Die for each Advantage beyond the first. For Example, 2 Advantages grants a D8, 3 Advantages grants a D10, and 4 Advantages grant a D12 Advantage Die. The following battlefield conditions give you an Advantage:
Defending while firmly entrenched behind significant terrain features such as a wall or barricade
Attacking an enemy who is unaware of you

A Disadvantage adds a D6 Disadvantage Die to your roll. A disadvantaged roll must choose the 2 lowest dice results and disregard the others. If you would have multiple Disadvantages, add a D6 for each Disadvantage and take the lowest 2 results. If the initial roll would only include 1 die, such as when suffering from Damage or an Injury, then disadvantaged rolls only choose the lowest result. The following battlefield conditions impose a Disadvantage:
Attacking a small target, such as a person, with a Mech Weapon
Ranged attacks against a target through obstructions to vision, such as smoke or other mechs
Ranged attacks made when an enemy is adjacent
Ranged attacks made at Long Range or Extreme Range (see Range on page 40)
Attacking an enemy who is Grabbing you

Each mech has a pool of Energy they can use for certain advanced Mech Weapons, Mech Traits, or for Boosting. Mechs start each encounter with an amount of Energy equal to their Energy Rating. At the start of each player’s Turn, their mech recovers 1 spent Energy. A mech can never have more Energy than their Energy Rating. For more info on Mech Weapons that use Energy, see the Mech Weapons section on page 40. And for more info on Mech Traits that use Energy, see the Traits section beginning on page 46.

Every mech can Boost by spending 3 Energy to add +1 to a dice result. You can do so after you roll your dice but before Hits are determined. This is most beneficial when adding +1 to a result of a 4 or 9 in order to gain additional Hits. You can Boost multiple times per action, but each dice result can only be Boosted once.

You can also Boost to add +1 to your Move Rating for the Turn. You can do so as many times as you’d like as long as you have the Energy to spend. The bonus to Move Rating lasts until the end of your Turn.

Line of Sight represents your ability to see the targets of your actions. It is an imaginary line drawn from the center of the attacker to the center of the target. If the Line of Sight passes through an obstruction, such as trees, smoke, or another mech, then the attacker receives Disadvantage on the attack. If the target of an attack is entrenched behind a substantial terrain feature which might absorb incoming attacks, such as a wall or barricade, then the defender receives Advantage on the Defend roll.

Each Mech Starts with 1 Mech Armor and may gain an Energy Shield or additional Mech Armor through Mech Traits. Each instance of Mech Armor or Energy Shields you possess can be expended once per Encounter to avoid Damage. However, Mech Armor cannot be used when Defending against an Armor Piercing Weapon. Energy Shields cannot be used when Defending against an Energy Piercing Weapon.

If a character is adjacent to an enemy and attempts to move away from them, that enemy may make an immediate Melee Attack against them as an Opportunity Attack. Rattled characters may not make Opportunity Attacks.

If you target an enemy that is adjacent to an ally and roll a 1, then one of your allies becomes the new target of the attack. If more than one of your allies is adjacent to the original target of your attack, then you may choose which ally becomes the new target. If you roll a 1 but also roll an Extra Hit, then you may spend an Extra Hit to negate the effect of the 1.

Any attempted attack with your mech which does not use a Mech Weapon, such as punching with a limb or attempting to step on a smaller target, is considered an Unarmed Mech Attack. When you make such an attack, make a Melee Attack Mech Action as normal. The Damage Rating for this attack is determined by a roll of your Arsenal Die and the Range is 1.

There is no legislated leveling or experience in Beamswords and Bazookas. However, if you’ve reached a significant milestone and want to signify this achievement with a character advancement, then players can gain a Bonus Trait. You should do so sparingly as it will significantly increase power level if done too often.

During an Encounter, each character’s actions are restricted to a Turn. When a character’s Turn comes up in the initiative order, the player may choose what actions their character takes and roll dice to see if these actions are successful. The actions available to them will differ depending on the scale of the Encounter and the Traits and Mech Weapons they possess.

On a character’s Turn during a Mech Encounter, each character can take a Mech Action, a Pilot Action, and a Move Action on their Turn. These actions can be taken in any order and the options available are described in detail later in this chapter. Here is a brief overview of the Mech Encounter action type:
Mech Actions are the primary functions that mechs perform, including attacking with Mech Weapons.
Pilots Actions are extra actions that characters perform in order to gain an edge in combat.
Move Actions allow mechs to travel a distance equal to their Move Rating.

On a character’s Turn during a Character Encounter, each character can take a Skill Action. Because distances are usually less strictly defined during a Character Encounter, characters are assumed to be able to move a reasonable distance on each Turn. However, an Acrobatics or Athletics Skill Action may be required to move a great distance or across difficult terrain.

If there’s ever an action you’d like to take that is not listed as a defined action in this section, that’s okay! That doesn’t mean you can’t attempt it. After-all, role-playing games are at their best when inventive solutions are applied to unorthodox problems. Explain your intentions to the gamemaster and work with them to figure out how best to resolve your action.

Each character can take one Mech Action on their Turn during a Mech Encounter. Specific Mech Actions are listed below. You can also sacrifice your Mech Action in order to take an additional Pilot Action or a Skill Action.
Ranged Attack - Roll Precision and Arsenal. On a Hit, your target must Defend vs. your Weapon’s Damage Rating. Each Extra Hit adds +2 Damage Rating for this attack. Requires a Ranged Mech Weapon.
Melee Attack - Roll Speed and Arsenal. On a Hit, your target must Defend vs. your Weapon’s Damage Rating. Each Extra Hit adds +2 Damage Rating for this attack.

Analyze - Roll Wits and Systems. On a Hit, gain information about an enemy or uncover a hidden adversary. In addition, your target has Disadvantage when they Defend against your next attack. On an Extra Hit, your target is Rattled. Being Rattled in this way does not cause Damage.
Challenge - Roll Toughness and Wits. On a Hit, give an opponent Disadvantage on their next action. On an Extra Hit, your target is Rattled. Being Rattled in this way does not cause Damage.
Recharge - Roll Wits and Systems. Regain 2 spent Energy for each Hit.
Bolster - Gain Advantage on all Defense rolls until the beginning of your next Turn. No roll needed.
Swap Weapons - You change which Mech Weapons are equipped to your Hardpoints. Weapons affixed with a Weapon Mount can only be changed outside of combat. No roll needed.

Rush - Roll Speed and Drive. On a Hit, move up to your Move Rating. On a failure, you can move up to half of your Move Rating, rounded down. Gain an Advantage on your next action that benefits from your new positioning for each Extra Hit.
Reload - If a Mech Weapon needs to be Reloaded, you cannot use it again until you take this action. No roll needed. You can Reload as many times as needed during an Encounter.

Suppressing Fire - Requires a Full Auto Mech Weapon. Roll Precision and Wits. On a Hit, each enemy in a 2x4 area within your Weapon’s Range has Disadvantage on their next action. You may Rattle an enemy in the targeted area for each Extra Hit. Being Rattled in this way does not cause Damage. You must Reload your Mech Weapon after using this action before you can use it again.

Spray Fire - Requires a Full Auto Mech Weapon. Roll Precision and Arsenal. On a Hit, each enemy in a 2x4 area within your Weapon’s Range must Defend against your Weapon’s Damage Rating. Each Extra Hit adds +2 Damage Rating for this attack. You must Reload your Mech Weapon after using this action before you can use it again.

Overwatch - Designate a 2x4 area within your Mech Weapon’s Range. Whenever an enemy enters this area, you may make one Ranged Attack against them. This attack triggers as soon as they enter the designated area. This effect ends at the beginning of your next Turn. No roll needed.

Grab - Make a Contested Toughness and Drive roll vs. an adjacent target. On a Hit, you grab your target and they cannot move away or target another enemy. They can attempt to break free on their Turn with a contested Maneuver or Grab action. Objects may be grabbed without rolling. Each Extra Hit grants Advantage against your target’s next attempt to break free or on your next attempt to Throw your target.

Throw - Make a contested Toughness and Drive roll vs. a target you have Grabbed. On a Hit, throw the object or enemy up to a Range of 6. On an Extra Hit, the thrown target and/or targets hit by your throw must Defend against a Damage Rating equal to a roll of your Drive Die and the thrown enemy’s Hull Die or a D6 if throwing an object. Alternately, Extra Hits can be spent to add +3 to the Throw Range.
Each character can take one Pilot Action on their Turn during a Mech Encounter. See below for the different Pilot Actions available. Some Traits will grant additional Pilot Action options.
Focus - You gain Advantage on your Mech Action for this Turn. No roll needed.
Maneuver - Roll Speed and Drive. You can move up to the number of Hits you roll and you ignore Opportunity Attacks when you do so.
Recover - Roll Wits and Systems. On a Hit, you remove the Rattled condition. Any Extra Hits allow you to remove 1 accumulated Stress.

Each character can take one Move Action on their Turn during a Mech Encounter. A Move Action allows your mech to move a distance equal to their Move Rating. You may take your Move Action before or after any of your other actions, but you may not split up your movement between other actions. Each square of difficult terrain requires two units of Move Rating to travel through. Attempting to move to a different elevation, either higher or lower terrain, requires two units of Move Rating. Moving diagonally on a square grid requires one unit of Move Rating.

Actions that rely on your character’s training and personal equipment rather than their ability to pilot their mech are Skill Actions. These actions are generally taken during Character Encounters to overcome an obstacle or initiate change. The dice you roll for a Skill Action will be a Character Attribute and a Skill Attribute. Skill Actions cover a wide range of activities and are therefore less restrictive than Mech Actions. The most common types of Skill Actions are listed for reference on the Skill Action Table on page 33.

When a character attempts to harm another character with a Skill Action, the first Hit scored will Rattle the target. Any Hits scored on a Rattled target will then deal an Injury. Targets of a Skill Action attack Defend by rolling Speed and Toughness in response. Hits on this Defense roll cancel out an equal number of Hits on the attack roll.

When Rattled, a character can attempt to remove the condition by taking a Willpower Skill Action. Willpower Skill Actions are made by rolling your Wits and Officer Attribute Dice and the Rattled condition is removed if a Hit is scored. Characters can also attempt to remove the Rattled condition from an ally using a Willpower Skill Action.

If multiple characters are attempting to accomplish the same thing at the same time, one character should attempt the Skill Action and other characters should attempt to Aid an Ally. Each character who is helping must explain what they are doing to assist and roll the appropriate Skill Action. Each Hit rolled when attempting to Aid an Ally will grant an Advantage on the specific task at hand. Once everyone has attempted to assist, one character will take a Skill Action that factors in all of the Advantages gained from the help provided.
During a Mech Encounter, a character may sacrifice their Mech Action to take a Skill Action instead.
A T T R I B U T E S

Attributes represent your character’s capabilities, skills, and the tools at their disposal. Each Attribute’s effectiveness is represented by an Attribute Die. Larger dice represent greater capability with an Attribute. You will roll your Attribute Dice when determining the success of your character’s actions. There are 3 different types of Attributes: Character Attributes, Mech Attributes, and Skill Attributes.
Character Attributes represent innate skill and aptitude. Every action you attempt, whether at Mech Scale or Character Scale, will include one of your Character Attribute Dice.

Precision - Precision represents your character’s accuracy and dexterity. It‘s used when shooting ranged weapons at Mech Scale and Character Scale. Precision is also used when finesse is required, such as for pick-pocketing or during stealth infiltration.

Speed - Speed represents your character’s quickness and agility. It is used for melee attacks at both Mech Scale and Character Scale. Speed is also applicable when quickness is a factor, such as when jumping a fence or driving a car.

Toughness - Toughness represents your character’s durability and strength. It is used when Defending at both Character Scale and Mech Scale. Toughness is used when physical power or fortitude is needed, such as when lifting, pushing, or swimming.

Wits - Wits represents your character’s mental capabilities. Wits are used when recovering from being Rattled at Mech Scale and Character Scale. Wits are widely applicable to skills ranging from knowledge of history and medicine to proficiency with computer and mechanical systems. Wits also represents a character’s charisma and ability to effectively communicate. Wits determines your character’s Stress Limit.
Mech Attributes represent your mech’s strengths and capabilities. You will roll a Mech Attribute Die as a part of most actions when piloting your mech.

Arsenal - Arsenal represents your mech’s offensive capabilities. It is a culmination of targeting ability, responsiveness, and firing platform stability. It is used for both ranged and melee attacks you make with your mech.

Drive - Drive represents your mech’s engine, drive-train, and mechanical locomotion. It is used when your mech’s movement or mechanical force is involved. It is critical in determining your mech’s Load Rating and Move Rating.
Hull - Hull represents your mech’s protective casing and general durability. It is used when Defending at Mech Scale.

Systems - Systems represents your mech’s operating computer and electronics suite. It is used to recover from being Rattled while piloting your mech and for a variety of support functions. It also determines your mech’s Energy Rating.

Skill Attributes represent your character’s training and personal gear. You will roll your Skill Attributes when taking Skill Actions, primarily during Character Encounters. You are assumed to have access to a suite of personal equipment unless specifically noted otherwise.

Agent - Agent represents your character’s training in espionage. Going undercover, sneaking into a building, cracking a safe, searching for clues, or tumbling through laser tripwires would all rely on your Agent Attribute.

Officer - Officer represents your character’s polish and professionalism. Being aware of your surroundings, keeping yourcomposure in a hectic situation, and being informed on the latest world events all rely on your abilities as an Officer. Officer also represents your ability to carry yourself in a conversation and would apply to schmoozing a CEO, intimidating a kingpin, or rallying a militia to your cause.

Soldier - Soldier represents your character’s ability to fight while not piloting their mech. You’ll use Soldier when engaged in a bar fight, when pulling a knife on someone, or when firing your sidearm. You’ll also use Soldier when attempting to hike, swim, or carry.

Specialist - Specialist represents your character’s specific expertise as well as their ability to comprehend complex situations quickly. It can range from hacking into a closed network, to sabotaging a drawbridge, or even flying a helicopter. Specialist can also be used when attempting to recall technical information.

A Mech Weapon must be equipped to a Hardpoint in order to be used. Each mech has 2 Hardpoints and Mech Weapons occupy 1 Hardpoint by default. Additional Hardpoints can be acquired through the Weapons Mount Mech Trait. Also, note that Mech Weapons with the Massive Tag must be equipped to 2 Hardpoints.

Any Mech Weapon currently equipped on a Hardpoint is considered active and may be used to attack. However, not all Mech Weapons you carry must be equipped to a Hardpoint. Inactive Mech Weapons may be stowed and later equipped to a Hardpoint using the Weapon Swap action. Mech Weapons equipped using the Weapons Mount Mech Trait cannot be swapped during combat.

The total Weight of your carried Mech Weapons and Mech Traits may not exceed your Load Rating, even if those Mech Weapons are not currently equipped to Hardpoints. Carrying less Weight than your Load Rating allows will increase your Move Rating. Dropping Mech Weapons in combat does not increase your Move Rating, nor does picking up objects momentarily decrease it. Load Rating and Move Rating represent design constraints and optimal tuning for long-term performance.

A Mech Weapon’s Range determines how far away you can be when you attack before suffering a range penalty. Attacks made against a target beyond a Mech Weapon’s Range have Disadvantage. Attacks made against targets that are beyond twice the Range of a Mech Weapon have 2 Disadvantages. Melee Mech Weapons cannot attack targets that are beyond their Range value.
Mech Weapons have Tags which denote special properties.
Ammo X - Can be fired X times before needing to take the Reload Mech Action

Area X - Attacks target each character in an X by X area which must be centered within the Weapon’s Range. Advantages and Disadvantages from cover, adjacency, and line of sight do not apply and attacks against smaller targets do not suffer Disadvantage.
Armor Piercing - Damage from this Mech Weapon cannot be avoided with Mech Armor
Cone - Attacks target each character in a cone which is 6 long and 6 wide. Advantages and Disadvantages from adjacency do not apply and attacks against smaller targets do not suffer Disadvantage.
Energy X - Costs X Energy each time you attack with this Mech Weapon
Energy Piercing - Damage from this Mech Weapon cannot be avoided with Energy Shields
Full Auto - Can use the Suppressing Fire and Spray Fire Mech Actions
Massive - Must be equipped to 2 Hardpoints and cannot be fired while grabbing an enemy
No Reload - This Mech Weapon doesn’t need to be Reloaded
Quick - Can Weapon Swap as a Pilot Action when equipping or un-equipping this Mech Weapon
Tactical - Ignore Disadvantage given to Ranged Attacks when an enemy is adjacent
Tags: Energy 2, Special: Spend 2 Energy to Gain Full Auto
Tags: Energy 4, Special: Hits Each Enemy
Tags: Energy 1, Quick, Energy Piercing, Armor Piercing

Traits define many of the special abilities for your character and mech. They might give you increased Ratings, additional action options, or allow you to modify certain rules. At character creation, you choose a Character Trait, a Mech Trait, and a Skill Trait. Then you can choose 3 Bonus Traits which can be any type. You may only select a Trait once unless it explicitly states otherwise.

Note that some Mech Traits have Weight which will need to be accounted for in your Load Rating calculations. Other Mech Traits have Energy Draw X which reduces your Energy Rating by X when you choose that Trait. You cannot choose a Trait with Energy Draw if it would reduce your Energy Rating below zero. Some Traits require that you have a different Trait before you can acquire them.
Character Traits have effects that impact both Mech Encounters and Character Encounters.
Ace - If you move more than your base Move Rating on your Turn, attacks against you have Disadvantage until the beginning of your next Turn. Gain Advantage on Driving Skill Actions.
Adrenaline Junky - Gain +2 Damage Rating to the next Melee Attack you make when you Boost your Move Rating. You gain Advantage on Driving Skill Actions.
Assassin - When you successfully attack an enemy who is unaware of you, they have Disadvantage on their Defense roll.
Battlefield Blur - You can make a Melee Attack as a Pilot Action after a successful Rush Action. You gain Advantage when Defending against Opportunity Attacks.
Blitz - You are dealt 2 initiative cards and may keep 1. You may spend Extra Hits on Rush actions to Rattled an enemy adjacent to your final position.
Brawler - Gain +6 to Damage Rating rolls for Unarmed Mech Attacks. You gain Advantage on Hand-to-Hand Combat Skill Actions.
Bred for Battle - Gain +3 Stress Limit.
Calm Under Fire - You may sacrifice your Move Action to Reload or Swap Weapons as a Pilot Action. Also, you gain Advantage on Willpower Skill Actions.

Crowd Combatant - Immediately after you make a Melee Attack Mech Action, you may attack a different enemy with a Melee Attack as a Pilot Action. When you make a Hand-to-Hand Combat Skill Action, you can target two adjacent enemies.
Duelist - You have Advantage when Defending against melee weapon attacks while you are equipped with a melee weapon. If you successfully Defend, the attacker is Rattled.
Electronics Whiz - Gain Advantage on Recharge Mech Actions and Computer Skill Actions.

Famous - Gain Advantage on either Charm or Intimidate Skill Actions based on the nature of your notoriety (choose when you take this Trait). Additionally, once per session, you can designate one character as being in awe of you. You have Advantage on all Skill Actions taken toward that character and they have Disadvantage on attacks against you.

Field Commander - You gain the ability to make a Command as a Pilot Action. To do so, roll Wits and Systems. For each Hit, give an Ally who can see you Advantage on their next action. Also, you gain Advantage on Influence Skill Actions.
Grappler - You can Grab or Throw as a Pilot Action. Also, you gain Advantage on Hand-to-Hand Combat Skill Actions.
Hardened Nerves - You receive 2 Stress instead of 3 when you Push to remove the Rattled condition. Also, you gain Advantage on Willpower Skill Actions.
Keen - You may Analyze as a Pilot Action. Also, you gain Advantage on Awareness Skill Actions.
Menacing - You can Challenge as a Pilot Action. Also, you gain Advantage on Intimidate Skill Actions.
Rage - Your attacks have +2 Damage Rating while you are Rattled. Also, you can still benefit from Advantages when Rattled.
Sharpshooter - Gain +2 Damage Rating when you Focus on a Ranged Attack. Also, you gain Advantage on Small Arms Skill Actions.
Symbol of Hope - Allies who can see you have Advantage on actions taken to remove the Rattled condition. Also, you gain Advantage on Influence Skill Actions
Tactician - You have Advantage on Analyze Mech Actions and Investigate Skill Actions.
Valor - When you take the Bolster Mech Action or an Intimidate Skill Action, adjacent allies may not be the targets of an attack if you could be the target instead.
Vengeful - After an adjacent enemy makes an attack against you, you may immediately make an attack against them.
Mech Traits greatly impact Mech Actions, Pilot Actions, and Move Actions. Mech Traits are generally used during Mech Encounters.

Active Camo - You may spend 3 Energy and take a Pilot Action to activate your Active Camo and make your mech invisible until the end of your next Turn. No roll needed. While invisible, enemies must make a successful Analyze Action to reveal you and you are no longer hidden once revealed. Enemies get Advantage on this Analyze Action if you have attacked while invisible.
Aerofoils - Requirements: Weight 1. You can fly and ignore difficult terrain, elevation, and enemies while moving. When you Boost to increase your Move Rating, you gain +3 instead of +1.
Afterburner - Requirements: Weight 1. You can Rush as a Pilot Action.
Combat Drone - Requirements: Scouting Drone Trait, Energy Draw 2. Increase your drone’s Attributes to a D8, its Move Rating to 6, its Range to 9, and its Damage Rating to 12.
Customized Weapons Loadout - Select 2 of the below upgrades and apply them to 1 Mech Weapon or 2 different Mech Weapons:
Reduce a Mech Weapon’s Weight by 1. It gains the Quick tag if it’s new Weight is 4 or less.
Increase a Ballistic or Beam Weapon’s Range by +3.
Give a Weapon with Range 9 or under the Tactical tag.

Deflector Shield - Requirements: Energy Shield Trait, Energy Draw 1. You can roll Systems instead of Hull when you Defend as long as you have not spent your Energy Shield. You cannot use this Trait against Mech Weapons with Energy Piercing.

Dual Controls - Requirements: Energy Draw 1. You can attack with a Mech Weapon equipped to only 1 Hardpoint as a Pilot Action. You may make an Unarmed Mech Attack as a Pilot Action instead if you have 1 unequipped Hardpoint.
Energy Shield - Requirements: Energy Draw 1. You gain an Energy Shield which can be spent to avoid 1 Damage per Encounter.

Experimental Personality Core - Requirements: Energy Draw 2. You may take any Mech Action as a Pilot Action. You receive an additional 1 Stress every time you would receive Stress. If you ever exceed your Stress Limit, the experimental personality within your mech takes over and unleashes its fury on your allies rather than your character suffering from Psychosis.
Helix Capacitor - Requirements: Weight 1. Gain 3 Energy Rating.
Hull Plating - Requirements: Weight 1. Gain 1 additional Mech Armor you can spend to avoid 1 Damage per Encounter.
Integrated Grenade Launcher - Requirements: Weight 1. Twice per encounter you can shoot a grenade of your choice:
Smoke Grenade: As a Pilot Action, shoot a smoke grenade with Range 6 that fills a 4x4 area with dark smoke.
Anti-Infantry Grenade: Range 6, Area 3. This grenade can only damage Infantry and kills them automatically if you score a Hit.
Countermeasure Flare: When you are targeted by a missile attack, you can shoot a flare in response to make the attack miss. You must do so before the roll is made.

Over-clocked Conductor - Requirements: Energy Draw 1. You may Boost to add +2 Damage Rating to a your next Beam Weapon Attack this Turn. You may do so any number of times per Turn if you have the available Energy.
Power Matrix - Requirements: Weight 1. Boosting costs 2 Energy instead of 3.
Rocket Fists - Unarmed Mech Attacks have a Range of 6.

Scouting Drone - Requirements: Energy Draw 2. You have a drone which you can direct to take Mech Actions as a Pilot Action. It has a D6 in all Attributes, a Move Rating of 4, a Range of 6, and a Damage Rating of 10. It is destroyed if Damaged.
Smart Missiles - When you attack with a Missile Mech Weapon, you may ignore any allies in the attack area.
Tow Cable - You can Grab with a Range of 6. You can Throw an enemy grabbed in this way, but only to pull them closer.

Transformation - For each other Mech Trait you choose, you may select an additional Inactive Mech Trait. You can switch between Active and Inactive Mech Traits with a Transform Pilot Action, no roll required. When you do, you may change equipped Mech Weapons as if you had taken the Swap Weapons Mech Action. You must meet all Requirements for all Mech Traits taken regardless of whether they are Active or Inactive.
Treads/Extra Legs - Requirements: Energy Draw 1. Gain +3 Load Rating and you ignore Difficult Terrain for movement.
Light Alloy - Gain 1 Move Rating and Advantage on Rush Actions.
Weapon Mount - Gain an additional Harpoint. Mech Weapons equipped to this additional Hardpoint cannot be unequipped during combat. You can choose this Trait multiple times.
Zeta Reactor - Requirements: Weight 1. You can Recharge as a Pilot Action.
Skill Traits enhance Skill Actions. Skill Traits are mainly used during Character Encounters.
Anti-Mech Weaponry - You can damage a mech with your Small Arms Fire or Hand-to-Hand Combat Skill Action. You have a Damage Rating of 10 when you attempt to do so.
Close Quarters Combat Training - You gain Advantage on Hand-to-Hand Combat Skill Actions.
Criminal Experience - You gain Advantage on Deception and Intimidate Skill Actions.
Espionage Training - You gain Advantage on Deception and Investigation Skill Actions.
Hacker Jack - You gain Advantage on Computer and Investigate Skill Actions.
Highly Educated - You gain Advantage on Culture and Science Skill Actions.
Interrogation Training - You gain Advantage on Awareness and Willpower Skill Actions.
Jetpack - You have a Jetpack and can fly. Skill Actions to control your Jet Pack are Precision + Agent. You may use this in place of Acrobatics or Athletics Skill Actions.
Leadership Training - You gain Advantage on Influence and Intimidate Skill Actions.
Media Training - You gain Advantage on Culture and Deception Skill Actions.
Medical Training - You gain Advantage on Medicine and Science Skill Actions.
Omnitool - You gain Advantage on Computer and Mechanics  Skill Actions.

Personal Vehicle - You gain a vehicle that can carry you and additional passengers. You gain Advantage on Drive Skill Actions when operating your vehicle and Mechanics Skill Actions. This vehicle can be stowed in the chassis of your mech.
Physical Conditioning - You gain Advantage on Acrobatics and Athletics Skill Actions.
Saboteur Training - You gain Advantage on Mechanics and Infiltrate/Stealth Skill Actions.
Sneaking Suit - You gain Advantage on Acrobatics and Infil-trate/Stealth Skill Actions.
Small Arms Training - You gain Advantage on Small Arms  Fire Skill Actions.
Tactical Armor - You gain Advantage whenever you Defend against an attack at Character Scale.
Tech Armor - You can use your Specialist Attribute in place of Toughness or Speed when Defending at Character Scale.
Survival Training - You gain Advantage on Athletics and Willpower Skill Actions.

Being the gamemaster gives you the privilege of setting plots into motion and weaving a web of story threads. Whether you’re creating your own adventures or running the Campaign in this book, here are some important things to keep in mind.

Set the Scene - Everyone is responsible for making the imaginary world you describe vivid, but you will be setting the example. Think of yourself as the narrator. You can paint the world around the characters with sights, sounds, and smells.  Insert tiny details that defy expectations and make characters think beyond the typical. Consider the things non-player characters might say and how they would say them. Have fun setting the stage for the players and your energy will carry over into how they approach the game.

Keep Things Moving - The pace of the game will greatly impact everyone’s enjoyment. Inject action when there isn’t much happening. Give players downtime if they haven’t had a moment to collect themselves. Vary the types of Encounters player’s face and keeping things moving forward. Be respectful of people’s time. Make sure you’re aware of when the game needs to end and try to accomplish the goals for the session in the allotted time.

Play the Opposition - You will control the non-player characters in the game as well as enemy combatants on the battlefield. Remember that creating a real challenge for the players ultimately makes them feel more accomplished when they succeed. So put them to the test! Make the enemies both dangerous and motivated. Attack them when they least expect it. And ingrain the opposition in the story so that they are memorable and noteworthy.

Navigate the Rules - Players will look to you to make final decisions on rules interpretations. And, if player’s are unfamiliar with the game, you may be teaching the rules as well. All of the rules contained in this book are meant to serve you. The story at the table should always supersede any concerns over small rule breaches. But consistently enforcing the rules will ultimately make everyone’s experience better. If you ever find yourself unsure of how to interpret a particular rule, go with the option that makes the moment more exciting.

Shine the Spotlight - Pay attention to the players. Take note of what their character’s are attempting to do and try to make it possible. Think about what enemies would be a good foil to their characters and contemplate what dramatic situations will allow them to best show their strengths. Try to make sure that everyone is receiving attention. If some players are less involved, make a point to ask them what they think and give them a chance to add to the story.

Mediate Disagreements - While conflict should never be only one person’s responsibility, you will often be looked to for guidance. Attempt to be upfront, direct, and understanding. People may enter into the game with different goals, concepts, or play-styles and tensions can sometimes rise over differing opinions. Addressing such disagreements directly is often best. Allow each player to discuss what they want from the story and the game in an out-of-character conversation if needed. Such a conversation may seem counter-productive to the immersive experience of a role-playing game, but talking about it directly can often avoid repeated conflicts and make everyone’s experience better. If the issues are more serious, such as one player being hostile or lewd towards another, then a private conversation or a reconsideration of the play group may be needed.

Beamswords and Bazookas games can be broken down into a series of Encounters with Downtime in between them. You might present the players with a mission that they need to accomplish or a situation that needs their attention. How they undertake that mission, or what they decide to do with the direction you give them, is up to them. Always allow players to make decisions, take agency, and get themselves into trouble. This is where the real fun is! You should have Encounters planned for each play session as players will look to you for direction. But, it’s equally important to be flexible and change Encounters if players decide on an unexpected course of action.

Character Encounters are adventures that happen outside a mech. As a general rule, each Encounter should have something the characters are seeking and something that gets in their way. If there’s no central conflict, then it likely doesn’t need to be an Encounter and can be described as a story element. Character Encounters should contain a number of obstacles that players need to overcome with Skill Actions. These can vary from gaining an allegiance with an elusive contact, to breaking into a high security facility, to escaping a crashing helicopter. The more variety, the better! After all, characters aren’t just mech pilots. They’re heroes who are trying to prevent the world from descending into madness. Things should get complicated and the challenges that players face could include almost anything.

Obstacles in character encounters are just as likely to be situations as they are enemy combatants. Players may need to blend in at an upscale event or investigate the scene of a crime. Such obstacles will have a Difficulty Rating which sets the number of Hits player’s will need on a Skill Action in order to succeed. Most actions will only need 1 Hit to succeed and are Difficulty Rating 1 by default. However, especially dangerous, difficult, or complex actions might be a Difficulty Rating 2 or 3. This difficulty is set by the gamemaster and should take all narrative factors into consideration.

No matter how difficult a task might be, you should never ask a player to take a Skill Action unless you can present a consequence of failure that presses the action forward. Sometimes, players will have ample time and resources to accomplish their goal. In those situation it’s perfectly fine to let them succeed without making a roll. However, interesting consequences are one of the best ways to crank up the intensity of a situation. Failure should make the game more fun for everyone when intriguing consequences are triggered.

If a player gets a Hit on a Skill Action but does not get enough Hits for a full success, a Complication should be introduced. Complication are impediments that prevent players from accomplishing their original goal. The complication should not imply failure. Remember that players should only fail on their attempted Skill Action if they don’t score any Hits on their roll. Complications should always increase the excitement of the situation in the same way that consequences of failure do.

There are many situation when players will be attempting to accomplish a goal together. If multiple characters are all taking the same Skill Action to attempt the same thing, it will detract from the consequences that might arise and will also add a sense of inevitability to the attempt. Instead, one player should be making the Skill Action to accomplish the goal and other players should be attempting to Aid an Ally. Players can take a variety of Skill Actions to Aid an Ally as long as it makes narrative sense. They will grant Advantage to another character’s next Skill Action for each Hit they score on their Aid an Ally roll.

As an example of an obstacle in a Character Encounter, imagine that characters are sent on an assassination mission. The first part of this mission involves them scaling a cliff in order to reach their target. If they had all the time in the world and all the equipment needed to make this climb, then it might not even require a Skill Action to accomplish. However, if characters have been stranded in the wilderness with no equipment and need to climb the cliff in a blizzard, it might be a Difficulty 3 Skill Action. Let’s say that characters have the equipment they need, but they have to make this climb quickly and quietly in order to avoid detection and it’s extremely windy. Under these conditions the same climb is a Difficulty 2 Skill Action. One of the players is pretty good at Athletics Skill Actions so they offer to make the roll for the climb. Another player says they are Aiding an Ally by keeping lookout. They roll an Awareness Skill Action and get 1 Hit. Therefore, the player making the Athletics Skill Action for the climb will have Advantage on the roll. However, they get unlucky and get 0 Hits on their attempted Skill Action. The consequence for failing this climb should probably not be that the characters fall to their deaths as this would grind the game to a halt. Instead, the consequence is that the climb takes longer than expected and the players arrive right as their assassination target leaves. Now they must figure out a way to pursue their target. Such a wrinkle adds a complication to the story while still amplifying the excitement and driving the action forward.

Sometimes Character Encounters have enemies that are actively trying to harm the players. In these instances, the Opposition is represented by a simplified Attribute Die called a Character Die. Each enemy character can make a Skill Action on their Turn and their Character Die should be used for all Skill Actions and Defense rolls. You should deal an initiative card to groups of enemies that might act together.
Easy Opposition has a D6 Character Die
Average Opposition has a D8 Character Die
Tough Opposition has a D10 Character Die
Fearsome Opposition has a D12 Character Die

It is important to give players an opportunity to recover Stress between encounters by allowing them to engage in either their Virtue or their Vice. As the gamemaster, this can often be as simple as asking the players what they do when they have a night off or a moment to catch their breath. There’s no additional game mechanic or dice roll involved in this phase of the game. It’s simply a time when everyone can add to the story by describing or acting out their character’s more personal moments. As the gamemaster, you just need to make sure that they’ve narratively engaged in their Virtue or Vice and give them story support when needed.

If your group likes to role-play, then you can just let them take control of this phase of the game. You should encourage player characters to interact with each other and have conversations during downtime. However, if they are already excited about describing what their characters are up to, then you can sit back and just make sure Downtime doesn’t run on too long.

If players are having a harder time thinking about what their character does during Downtime, then you might need to introduce some story elements that specifically allow them to engage in their Virtue or their Vice. Introducing characters they can interact with during this phase is a great way to give them story opportunities. And describing their environment or places of interest can be a great way to inspire fun scenes.

Note that Downtime doesn’t always have to be “time off”. Perhaps characters have a quiet but emotionally charged transit from one hot zone to another. What do they do while they sit in the transport? Are they quiet and full of anxiety about the mission ahead or are they overcompensating by being as loud and obnoxious as possible? These sorts of little details can add a lot of depth to the story. Small, stolen moments are perfectly viable as a time for players to engage in their Virtue or Vice.

Mech Encounters are large scale fights between mechs, monsters, and armies that take place across cityscapes and countrysides. These Encounters use miniatures to represent character placement and a grid or ruler to accurately measure distances. Once player characters and enemy units are set up in their starting positions, Initiative cards should be dealt. Enemy units should be grouped for initiative by similar unit types or in squadrons. Play then proceeds in Turn order based on the dealt Initiative Cards, from highest to lowest.

Because of the tactical nature of Mech Encounters, you should include terrain features that make the battlefield more dynamic. Difficult Terrain is anything that’s hard for characters to move through and might be a stream or a neighborhood of small houses. Players will have to spend double the Movement to move through the Difficult Terrain. Elevated Terrain is an area significantly above the battlefield and might include a cliff side or the roof of a large building. Players will have to spend double the movement to ascend or descend these higher terrain features. Obscuring Terrain affects visibility and might be a thicket of trees or a cloud of mist created by a waterfall. Attempting to shoot through such areas will give Disadvantage to the shooter. And Blocking Terrain cannot be moved through or seen through such as a large wall or monument. Players might be able to use such features for cover and gain Advantage on Defense rolls against ranged attacks.

Enemy units at Mech Scale can take a Move Action and either a Pilot Action or a Mech Action on their Turn, but not both. If an enemy unit would take Damage, they are defeated. Also, enemy units do not have Stress or Energy and cannot Push or Boost. Enemy units use a simplified Character Die to replace all Character Attributes and a Mech, Vehicle, or Monster Die to replace all Mech Attributes. Guidance on creating your own enemy units as well as example enemy units can be found later in this chapter.

A Villain Mech functions just like a player character in all regards. Villain Mechs have Energy and Stress and can Boost and Push. A Villain Mech is defeated if it receives Damage to all 4 Mech Attributes or suffers from a Psychosis effect.

Giant Monsters occupy a 2x2 area and receive 3 initiative cards instead of just 1. They can take a Move Action and either a Mech Action or a Pilot Action on each of their 3 Turns per round. Giant Monsters have Body Parts which must be attacked separately. Each Body Part can be individually Rattled and Injured and will have an effect on the Giant Monster’s capabilities if Injured. A Giant Monster is defeated when each Body Parts is Injured. Giant Monsters can Push, but do not suffer Psychosis if they exceed their Stress Limit. When a Giant Monster takes the Recover action, it may remove the Rattled condition from a Body Part for each Hit it scores. Attacks that affect an area, such as a missile attack or Spray Fire, can target multiple parts of a Giant Monster in the same attack and the attack should be Defended separately by each Body Part.

Use Mech Encounter Points in order to calculate a balanced enemy threat. When preparing enemy combatants for a Mech Encounter, allot 5 Encounter Points for each player and spend those points to field enemy units at the following rate:
Infantry or Vehicle Units cost 1 Encounter Point

Mech synergies and combat conditions can greatly affect a battle’s difficulty. You can adjust the allotted Encounter Points to suit your needs. If your group is especially experienced with tactical games and uses synergies to their advantage, you can allot 6 or 7 Encounter Points per player for difficult battles. If you want to ease the difficulty or have encounters that happen back-to-back with no chance to recover Stress in-between, then you may want to allot 3-4 Encounter Points per player.
Below are baselines for creating custom enemy mechs of different difficulty levels.
Load Rating: 4 (Assign Mech Weapons of up to 4 total Weight)
Load Rating: 5 (Assign Mech Weapons of up to 5 total Weight)
Choose 3 Elite Upgrades for each Elite Mech:
Veteran: Increase the Character Die to a D10
Upgraded: Increase the Mech Die to a D10
Advanced: Can use Energy Weapons at no Energy cost
Mobile: Gain +2 Move Rating and ignore Difficult Terrain
Dangerous: Can take a Mech Action and a Pilot Action on its Turn

For significant enemy characters of your campaign, create them as you would a player’s character using the steps on page 10. Track and use Stress and Energy just like a player‘s character would. Villain Mechs can take both a Mech Action and a Pilot Action on their Turn. Villain Mechs take Damage just as a player character would and are not defeated until they receive Damage to each Mech Attribute or exceed their Stress Limit.
Mech Weapon attacks against this target have Disadvantage.
Stinging Tail: DR 10, Range 1. Energy Piercing
Mech Weapon attacks against this target have Disadvantage.

Melee Weapon: Damage Rating 11, Range 1, Shield Piercing, Quick
Missile Pod: Damage Rating 10, Range 6, Ammo 3, Area 2
2-Hand Melee: Damage Rating 13, Range 2, Energy Piercing
Heavy Beam Cannon: DR 14, Range 9, Armor Piercing
Can use Energy Weapons without expending Energy.
Machine Gun: Damage Rating 12, Range 9, Full Auto

Can use a Mech Action and a Pilot Action on its Turn.
Melee: Damage Rating 11, Range 1, Quick, Energy Piercing
Pistol: Damage Rating 10, Range 6, Quick, Tactical
Bazooka: Damage Rating 14, Range 9, Ammo 1, Area 6
Can use a Mech Action and a Pilot Action on its Turn.
2-Hand Beam Melee: DR 13, Range 2, Armor and Shield Piercing
Beam Pistol: DR 10, Range 6, Quick, Tactical, Armor Piercing
Can use Energy Weapons without expending Energy.
Missile Launcher: Damage Rating 12, Range 6, Ammo 2, Area 4
SMG: Damage Rating 11, Range 6, Full Auto, Tactical
Precision D12, Speed D6, Toughness D10, Wits D8
Arsenal D12, Drive D8, Hull D10, Systems D6
Agent D6, Officer D10, Soldier D12, Specialist D8
